I those who took part Marion Jones, Maysville. Helen Wharton, James Riv er. Sue Gox, Curdsville. Laura Ayers, Slate River. Katie White, Marshall. Miss Helen Wharton won 1 st honor in this contest. There was a splendid audi ence assembled in the Baptist church to witness these con tests and n hen all was over the audience was told that a speak er from Richmond would be there to address them. Mr. Walker was that man, but he came to Wingina instead of to Dillwyn and got theie too late. While we were waiting for the speaker to come, little Miss Lu- cile Jones sang a solo, in a sweet childish voice that com pletely captivated the audience and was compelled to repeat the Bong by tne continued ap plause given her. The exercises were opened with prayer, led by Rev. J. J. Spencer, who thanked the Lord for the great blessing of peace that had come to the world. Stonewall Nov. 11 Glenfall Nov. 13 Vera Nov. 15 Hixburg Nov. 18 Pamplin Nov. 20 Evergreen Nov. 25 Spout Spring Nov. 26 I will be at Appomattox with Ml tax books on Nov. 28 and you can pay up to and including Dec. 31st before penalty will be added. document.text: H ixburg. Mr. E. H. Winston, of Rich-  mond, is spending a few days at the home of Mis. Wm. Danl. j Hix. Miss Elizabeth Wall, of  Richmond, and Miss Merle Davis, of Pampiin, spent a few days with Miss Margaret Gil liam this week. The Presbyterian meeting commences at this place on Wednesday night. Why is it we so seldom see a write up from Pampiin for we I know such a wide-awake and hustling place has some news of interest to all. The writer was at Pampiin on last Satur day and saw twenty-seven au tomobiles in and about the place some from South Caro lina, one from Danville, one from West Virginia, and one from Appomattox, in which our County Treasurer R. F. Burke, was traveling at a high speed.

document.text: NOTICE Spout Spring, y., Oct. 16,1915. To the V oters of Appom attox County Gentlemen I notice that Messrs. L. E. Sm ith, Chairm an C. M. Drinkard and M. W. Car- son, constituting the Hoard of Supervisor ?, have circulated generally over the county a circular in which thrv briiv direct charges again t m yself aud the C itizens Party. I will now proceed to answ er said charges but before doing so, I w ish to lay dow n this pr nciple There is but one rule of con duct for a manto do th right thing The cost m ay be dear in m oney, in friends, in in fluence, in labor, in a prolong ed and painful sacrifice but the cost not to do right is far more dear you pav in the in t grity of your m anhood, in honor, in truth, in character. You forfeit vour pou I s content, and for a tim ely gain you bar ter the iufinities. They say,  Statem ents have been m ade in their platform , in anonym ous circulars and car toons and by word of m outh by the candidates of the so-cal le d Citizens P arty that th e y  truth, favor a reduction of taxation . We certainly claim and stand for a reduction in taxation and this can be accom plished by an honest and econom ical adm inis tration of the countys affairs, w ithout hurt or injury to schools or roads. W e are in favor of im proving the schools of the county and to this end we favor the elections by the people of School Superinten dents and Trustees.  W ould they reduce the am ount of m oney being expend ed on public roads? We would ieduce the am ount of m oney being expended on special roads and for the bene fit of the ring, believing that ihe countys m oney should be expended for the benefit of the m asses and not for the classes.  The m oney can not be ex pended unless it is raised by taxation This is a fact but w e have been told that the people do not p a y such and such a debt as it is paid by the State, trying o m ake the pe pie believe w hat is false in principle as w ell as in practice  W e call attention of he voters to tho fact th at the rate of taxation im posed last year for State and county purposes was exactly the sam e th at it w as in 1901 when Dr. D. Mott Robertson w as . Treasurer of this C ounty. This is a statem ent m ade to deceive os the follow ing figures will prove Amount of levy for 1901 for State and all County purposes 1 20. A m ount of levy for 1914 for State and Go. purposes 1.55 m aking a difference againt last year of 35c. plus 50c. capitation tax. Let us go still farther into this rate of taxation we w il compare tw elve years unde the adm inistration of D Mott Robertson as Treasurer w ith tw elve years under R. F Burke as Treasurer and note the difference Twelve years under D. Mott Robertson, Treasurer

document.text: Mrs. Bettie Burke Oden, wife of B. F. Oden, secretary to Congressman H. D. Flood, died at a hospital in Lynch burg following an operation for apt pendicitis. She was 26 years old and lived at Appomattox. Her father, R. I F. Burke, is treasurer of Appomattox j county. She is survived by a 3-year- , old daughter.

document.text: Mr. A. H. Clement desires it to be understood that he is in the can vass and will endeavor to visit the homes of the people of the county, but that he has been interfered with n some respects by unforeseen cir cumstances. The Baptist ministers of the Ap pomattox Association will meet to day to discuss the needs of the field ind to arrange a tentative program for the Association which meets at Charlotte C. H., August 18. Rev. Hugh Smith attends from this place. Capt. R. S. Echols, who was so badly injured by the wreck between Petersburg and Richmond last Fri day and who was reported to have been killed, is now here on a fair way to permanent recovery. Engi neer Covington and Fireman Cov ington, of the ill-fated train, were killed. All of these gentlemen were well and favorably known in this, county. The following officers qualified on Monday before Judge Christian in the county court, their terms being extended to January 1,1904, under the new Constitutiou S. P. Coleman, sheriff Leon. E. Smith, commissioner of revenue J. W. Paris, superintendent of poor J. R. Horsley, county surveyor W. H. Ligon, J. C. Jones, supervisors. R. F. Burke qualified as treasurer, vice l. Mott Robertson, resigned. It is rumored that T. J. Stratton will stand for road Commissioner in Stonewall, J. F. Dickerson for Gloyer Hill, and Hon. J. C. Jones- and Saml Lee has announced them selves candidates in Southside. No candidate has come out for Super visor for Stonewall, and Hon. W. Hi Ligon has no opposition in Clovef Hill for his old place on the board. Messrs. J. H. Robertson and Ed ward Harvey are candidates for Supervisor from Southside. Quite a surprise was sprung on the village yesterday when Mr. W. D. Cofer, came down from Blue field, W. Va., and secured a license for the marriage of Miss Lizzie Fleshman, which happy event will be celebrated to-day at the home of the brides father in a quiet way. The brides pastor Rev. Hugh C. Smith will officiate. The couple will leave on the evening train for a trip east and will be permanently located in Bluelield, where the groom holds a lucrative position with the N.  W. Ry. Co. The bride is a very charming young lady and de- servingly popular with

document.text: Heres an hitherto unpublished story about the war, and it qual ifies for the Truth is stranger than fiction column.  When the late beloved R . F . Burke, former Appomattox county treasurer and bank president, was lad of nine years, he was stay ing with his grandparents, Mr. and William Blunt at Pleasant Hill in Nottaway county. The War Between The States was raging all around them., A stiff ekfrmish frmas waged right at them. As Federal soldiers ap proached, the slaves were ordered to take the horses down near the river bank and hide them. Young Mr. Burke went with them. On the way back to the house, they were met by some Yankeie soldiers. The soldiers badly fjrightenied both the slaves and the young white master. They seemed to pick on the latter, but he talked right up to them. Then his nose started to bled... .always when he got excit ed his nose would bleed. And the blood trickled down on his white shirt. Just fit that -moment la Iktndly Federal officer came up. He saw what was going on, and rescued the boy. He took him on his horse and rode him up to the house and soothed his ruffled feelings. But when his grandmother saw the blood on his shirt she thought he had been wounded...a fear that was allayed when his experience was related. Now.. . . the scene jumps to Ap pomattox . Years. . . . many years.  later, when M r.R.F.Burk became Appomattoxs most successful citizens, a man came.. a veteran of the Federal army, came to Appo mattox to see the scenes of the Surrender. He asked to spend the night in the Burke home. During the evening the conversation cent ered on the war days ___ and, yes . .youve guessed i t . .. .he was none other than the Federal officer who had rescued the nine year old boy from this tormentors

document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Hors- rv, Sam Coleman, George J. Hundley, Robt. F. Hutcheson and Joel W. Flood. COUNTY JUDGESLewis Daniel Isbell, Henry T. Par-  rish and David A. Christian. TRIAL JUSTICEST. R. Horseley and L. F. Ferguson. COUNTY CLERKSJohn T. Bocock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, Geo. W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Claude W. Smith. , COMMONWEALTHS ATTORNEYSThos. S. Bocock, L. D. Isbell, Crawford Jones, Edward Woodson, T. J. Thornhill, David A. Christian, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson, Joel W. Flood and W. M. Abbitt. SHERIFFSJoel Watkins, Geo. T. Peers, William Paris, Wilson Hix, W. T. Johnson, Wm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, T. B. Bryant, S. P. Coleman, Frank W. McKinney and H. W. Mc Kinney. COMMISSIONERS OF THE REVENUEThos W. Johns, Isaac Adams, Andrew B. Baker, John W. Gilliam, Geo. W. Ab bitt, Van Gilliam, Wm. Statham, L. E. Smith, H. C. Babcock, E. R. Abbott and J. H. OBrien. COUNTY TREASURERSWm. H. Gills, Cooch Plunkett, S. R. Franklin, D. Mott Robertson, R. F. Burke and R. L. Burke. SUPERINTENDENTS OF SCHOOLSC. H. Chilton, J. B. Bristow, J. K. Hannah, N. R. Featherston and J. A. Burke. STATE SENATORSThe County has furnished the fol lowing State SenatorsCol. Wyatt Elliott, Col. Samuel D. Mc Dearmon, Col. Robt. B. Poore, H. D. Flood, Samuel L. Ferguson and Chas. T. Moses. HOUSE OF DELEGATESThe following citizens of the county have served in the House of Delegates Col, Samuel D. McDearmon, Zachariah Cheatham, Crawford Jones, R. P. Poore, Joel W. Flood, Thos. S. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. Cawthorn and R. L. Burke. The Constitution of 1902, abolished the County Court, the duties of which were transferred to the Circuit Court, the County Clerk and the Board of Supervisors.

document.text: In the County Court here Thurs day, the grand jury indicted the ne gro James for murder. His counsel, Messrs. Poor aud Flood, at once com menced the fight for bail, which the Court granted and fixed at 1,000, which has not been given yet, and James rests in jail. The trial was continued to Friday, the 17th. R. F. Burke .was appointed to fill out the unexpired term of the Treasurer from July to January 1st,. A. B. Thornhill qualified as cura tor of the estate ot the late A. E. Miltimore, bond 1000, H. D. Agent  Ernest E. Gills Thin esteemed county man passed away at his home here Saturday evening at 8 oclock and soon after his home was crowded with friends of the family. Ernest quit the road and came home to die of an incurable diseasebrighls. He lingered for two months under the care of his physicians and traiued nuise and yielded up the fight Saturday. He had been a fhithful representative of tbe Craddock Terry Shoe Co. for thirty years and in all hie dealings with the public and bis concern ho was frank and correct and eujoyed their confi lence and eBteem. He had been a deacon in his churcb here for many years, had serv ed his Masonic Lodge from the Jay of its organization And in every trust he has proven loyal and faithful. He was popular with those who knew him and his daily walk was by tbe faith of bis Master. He was 57 years of age and was a son of W. H. Gills of this county, who served tbe county at one time as treasurer. He is survived by bis widow and four children Miss Louise, Robert, James and Teddy. He also leaves two devoted broth ere VV. P Gills, App. mattox and James Gills, of Lynchburg. Rov. H. P. East preached tbe sermon while the Masonic lodge bad charge of the servic es, R F. Burke and District Deputy Master C. N Danfortb of Burkeville were masters of the lodge and his body was interred in Liberty cemetery. The pall bearers were R L Burke, Dr D N. Twyman, Dr. IV. D. Quid, C. W. Hancock, A. T. Inge and L. E Smith. Toe honorary pall bearers were A. R. Harwood, J. T. Jheatham, J. R. Caldwell, J.JT. Cole, Geo. W. Colemao, Dr. J B. Abbitt, Don Moses,.0 A. Hancock, J. W. Cawthom and E F. Sbtffey. Tbe Monroe Lodge assisted by the lodges at Pamplin and Concord.

document.text: Washington.Weather maps to eight layers, showing wlint conditions the aviator may expect when he lies hath low and high, are now being made regularly as a part of the official government weather report. Ground weufher observations alone have been found to be Inadequate for dying use. and the hlgh-altltude ob servations have also been found use ful in making the regular weather forecasts. In fact, the wenther seems to brew at the higher levels, and the observations, obtained by small bal loons and kites, often give Informa tion unobtainable nt the level of the earths surface. 43 Balloon Stations Send Data. The data used In the npper-atr weather maps come to the weather bureau from forty-three halloon sta tions throughout the country. The army has eighteen, while the navy tins ten balloon stations and one air- nlane observer. The wenther burenu also receives alr-aloft reports of temperature and humidity from five stations where kites are sent up with raeteorollglcal In struments. As kites are dependent upon wind, the wenther bureau Is about to try out a small captive bal loon. lust large enough to carry the oecessury Instruments, at Due West, S. C for use when Fhe air Is light. Helicopters will replace balloons and kites In the future. In the opinion ot Mr. Mitchell. Slvew Bumpy Air. Bumpy air, which makes rough rid ing for flyers. Is dearly shown by these kite reports. One recent re- laid from Orosheck, Texas, showed three strata of air-In an altitude of 1,800 meters. A meter Is a little more than three feet. The complete aero- logical observation map gives wind direction, velocity, kind and direction of clouds, and visibility as at surface. 250 meters above, 500 meters. 1,000 meters, 1,500 meters, 2,000 meters, 3,000 meters and 4,000 meters above. The balloons sometimes achieve much higher altitudes. The origin of the wind, whether polar or tropical. It is alleged that such proceedings as were carried on four years ago were very distasteful to many of the citizens of the county and for that reason the rank and file of voters are slow to express their choice for fear of the recurrence of hostile feeling. While no doubt man j have de cided views a to whom they will vote for, but little or no pub lic demonstrations have taken place throughout the county and while a few public gatherings have been held, the attendance at these meetings have been small and little interest in such meetings have been manifested. For the house of delegates, Col. A. J. Terrell is opposed by D- N. Gannaway, both of Buck ingham. Colonel Terrell being a candidate for what is called the organizations forces and Mr, Gannaway representing t h e antis. In this, like other county contests, there has been no issue and the fight hangs chiefly on personalities. In some quarters, the question of the short ballot issue has been in jected in which Mr. Gannaway ias declared himself as opposed to the short ballot, while no such statement has come from Mr. Terrell other than he is for the administration policies. As the short ballot, is an administra tion policy, however, it is regard ed that Mr. Terrell is for it, and su far, that is about the main is sue involved between the two candidates for that office. With but four more days be fore election more activity is teen on every hand and the poli tical pot is warming up to a con siderable degree in some of the local fights. For treasurer R. L. Burke is opposed by Dr. D. N. r wyman for commissioner of revenue Richard OBrien is op posed by George Purdum for supervisor Don Moses and C. A- OBrien, the incumbent, is opposed by E. M. Drinkard, ant n Stonewall district Sam Ander on, the incumbent, is being op- tost d by A. B. Thornhill. document.text: MRS. JAMES B. ABBITT Mrs. Vara W. Burke Abbitt, the widow of Dr. James B. Abbitt, died Friday afternoon at 4 oclock, after an illness of several months. She was a former deputy treasurer of Appomattox County. .She was the daughter of the late Richard F. and Alice Sears Burke. For the last twen ty years she had made her home here and was deputy treasurer until her retirement in 1953. She was prominently identified with civic and religious activities both here and in Norfolk where she had previously re sided. She was a member of the Daughters of the American Revolu tion and the United Daughters of the Confederacy. She was a past president of the Medical Auxiliary of the Norfolk Medical Society. She was an active member of the Liberty Baptist Church here, where she taught a Bible class for many years. Surviving are two daughters, Miss Vay Abbitt and Mrs. C. D. .Staples, both of Bon Air a niece, Mrs. Lee Covington, of Raleigh, N. C. three granddaughters a sister, Mrs. W. T. Steele, of Appomattox two broth ers, Richard L. Burke and Jerry A. Burke, both of Appomattox, and a number of nieces and nephews in addition to Mrs. Covington, whom she reared. Funeral services were held from Liberty Baptist Church at 200 P. M. Sunday, conducted by the pastor, Dr. Carl A. Collins, Jr., assisted by Dr. Twyman Williams. Burial was in Liberty Cemetery. Active pall bearers were Robert A. Sears, Jerry A. Burke, Jr. Richard F. Burke, III R. F. B. Steele, W. T. Steele, Jr. Richard F. Burke, Josh ua Pretlow, and John D. Abbitt.

It is alleged that such proceedings as were carried ou four y ean ago were very distasteful to many of the citizens of the county and for that reason the rank and file of voters are alowto express their choice for fear of the recurrence of hostile feeling. While no doubt man i have de cided views a to Whinm they will vote for, but little or no pub lic demonstrations have taken place throughout the county and while a few public gatherings have been held, the attendance at these meetings have been small and little interest in such meetings have been manifested. For the house of delegates, Col. A. J. Terrell is opposed by D- N. Gannaway, both of Buck ingham. Colonel Terrell being a candidate for what is called the organizations forces and Mr. Gannaway representing t h e antis. In this, like-other county contests, there has been no issue and the fight Thangs chiefly on personalities. In some quarters, the question of the short ballot issue has been in- jected in which Mr. Gannaway las declared himself as opposed to the short ballot, while no such statement has come from Mr. errell other than he is for thé administration policies. As the short ballot, is an administra tion policy, however, it is regard ed that Mr. Terrell is for it, and in fa r, th at is ft hour, r.hw m ain sue involved between the two candidates for that office, With but four more days be fore election more activity is leen on every hand and the poli- ical pot is warming up to a con- dderable degree in some of the ocal fights. For treasurer R. L. Burke is opposed by Dr. D. N. r wyman for commissioner of revenue Richard OBrien is op posed by George Pürdum for supervisor Don Moses and C. S. McDearmon are both candidates for Southside district to be made vacant by D. N. Twyman, the incumbent, who w running for treasurer  in Cloverhill district F. A. OBrien, th incumbent, is opposed by E. M. Drinkard, ant n Stonewall district Sam Ander son, the incumbent, is being op- osed by A. B. Thornhill. During the past few days quite i contention has arisen over an ict of the registrars who have either by error of ignorantly sent jut two different kinds of in structions to voters who wish to vote by mail, this vote will be heavy. Every available voter s being solicited for his or hèr vote whether they are in the

document.text: CONCERN Whereas, on April 10th, 1913, a resolution was dopted by he Dem ocratic County Committee of Appo mattox County, providing for a Pri mary Election to nominate Candi da.es for County and District Offi cers of Apjgomattox County,_ an also providing that all can.idar.cs for nomination for County and Dis trict Offices, as well as members of the Legislature of Virginia, should give no.ice of their candidacy, to the Chairman of said County Com mittee, as provided by law, on or before sixty days prior to the date of said primary, and Whcre s, the following persons for the offices set opposite their names, are the only candidates in said county who have filed their notices, according to law, and i n compliance with said resolution, to- wit For Commonwealth Attorney, W. M. Abbitt For County Treasurer, R. L. Burke . For County Clerk, C. W. Smith For Sheriff, H. W. McKinney For Commissioner of the Reve nue, J. H. OBrien For Clover Hill District Officers For Supervisor, F. A. OBrien For Southside District Officers For Supervisor, George Abbitt, Jr. For Justice of the Peace, T W. Moses Now, therefore, I, W. M. Abbitt, Chairman of the Democratic Execu tive Commit.ee of Appomattox Co unty, by virtue of the provision of the Democratic Party Plan, hereby declare aforementioned parties to be the Democratic Nominees for the offices set opposite their respective names, except for State Senate and Member of the House of Delegates, who have been by proper authori ties declared the nominees, to be voted for in the General Election to be held on Tuesday Nov. 2nd, 1943 and as such nominees entit led to the support and votes of all Democrats, the same as if they had been chosen in a primary election, andWhereas, more than one candi date for the office of Supervisor in Stongwall District have filed their notices of candidacy with me, a s provided by said resolution afore said, their names and the offices for which they are candidates res pectively, will be certified by me as provided by Sec. 230 of the pri mary law to the Electoral Board of Appomattox Oouny, to be by it printed on the primary ballot. Given under my hand this 7th day of June, 1943. W. M. Abbitt, Chairman Democratic County Executive Com- mi tee of Appomattox County. 6-10-ltc

document.text: Supervisors a n d county of ficials of Appomattox county met at the court house Tues-  day night of this week and agreed to a slashing of the county tax rate and salaries.j The tax-rate will be cut t 1.50 and salaries will be - duced 10 per cent, it fit. agreed. The present i levies run from 1.80 to 1.95. The reduction is expected to cause a bolstering of confidence locally and will be warmly wel comed by tax payers. No con certed demand for a reduction had been made by citizens, but the supervisors and county of f a l s felt that the cut was in .ine with steps already taken by several other counties. The supervisors also felt it best to act in advance of widespread dissatisfaction that might be forthcoming if theratewere not . educed and wisely averted any m a s s meetings of tax payers such as a number of other coun ies have experienced. Th i s act is expected to renew confi dence in the administration of county affairs, and cooperation -vill now be sought in an effort -o avoid drastic cut in upkeep jf roads and the conduct of the jchools. The- statement signed by county supervisors, follows To T h e Taxpayers of Appo mattox Count Realizing the financial con dition of the farmers and citi zens of our county, brought about by the drought of last year, a n d the unprecedented depression whichwe are pass ing, and small demand and low prices for all farm products, and while all of us now receive the lowest salary and compen sation allowed by state laws, but desiring to help relieve the tax burden of o u r people to some extent, hereby express cur willingness and voluntarily agree to accept a ten per cent cut in salary or compensation for the year beginning January 1st, 1932, and pledge ourselves to do everything possible to practice economy in the admin istration of the county affairs, so that the county, school and road levy m a y be reduced to the lowest possible figure. The above ten per cent does not ap ply to the County Treasurer or the Commissioner of the Rev enue, as the reduction in levy automatically reduces their compensation more than ten per cent. C. W. Smith, Clerk R. L. Burke, County Treasurer Jo el W. Flood, Commonwealth Attorney H. W. McKinney, Sheriff J. H. OBrien, Comr. of Revenue J. A. Burke, Supt, of Schools F. A. OBrien, Supervisor Don Moses, Super visor T. E. Owen, Supervisor E. LeRoy Smith, Chairman School Board ,T. J. Ligon, Member School Board j  o! Davidson, Member School Board. ,, 111 viw of the, foregoing, we iu undersififned members of th e Board of Supervisors, whose duty it is to make up the bud get and fix the levy bf the coun ty, desire to state that we wish to do everything we can to low- er the tax rate to t h e lowest possible figure, consistent with sound financing and safeguard ing the institutions of our coun ty. We are sure we can make a substantial reduction in the levy for th e next fiscal year, and agree to make the total levy 1.50 on the 100.00 for all purposes, thus reducing the taxes of the people approxi mately 12,450.00. We real ize this means a substantial cut in county affairs, road building, and length of school term. This includes a reduction in the sal aries and wages of everyone employed by the county, but we feel that an emergency exists , Continued on Page 4
